articles.headline: G.M. Says New Loan Is Adequate to Save It
articles.snippet: G.M. projects a $6.6 billion surplus by 2012, but the Obama administration must decide if that is realistic as it reviews the company’s latest loan request.
articles.abstract: G.M. projects a $6.6 billion surplus by 2012, but the Obama administration must decide if that is realistic as it reviews the company’s latest loan request.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors vowed on Wednesday that its latest request for federal aid would be the last it would need to carry it through the biggest reorganization in its history.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: A Swiss Bank Is Set to Open Its Secret Files
articles.snippet: UBS has agreed to divulge the names of Americans suspected of using offshore accounts to evade taxes.
articles.abstract: UBS has agreed to divulge the names of Americans suspected of using offshore accounts to evade taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the hush-hush world of Swiss banking, the unthinkable is happening: secrets are spilling into the open.

articles.headline: Lebanese in Shock Over Arrest of an Accused Spy
articles.snippet: Investigators say Ali al-Jarrah confessed to a career of espionage for Israel spectacular in its scope and length.
articles.abstract: Investigators say Ali al-Jarrah confessed to a career of espionage for Israel spectacular in its scope and length.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARAJ, Lebanon  For 25 years, Ali al-Jarrah managed to live on both sides of the bitterest divide running through this region. To friends and neighbors, he was an earnest supporter of the Palestinian cause, an affable, white-haired family man who worked as an administrator at a nearby school.

articles.headline: Kansas Governor Seen as Top Choice in Health Post
articles.snippet: Gov. Kathleen Sebelius is emerging as President Obama’s top choice for secretary of health and human services.
articles.abstract: Gov. Kathleen Sebelius is emerging as President Obama’s top choice for secretary of health and human services.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas, an early Obama ally with a record of working across party lines, is emerging as the president’s top choice for secretary of health and human services, advisers said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Bonus Cuts Hurting More Than Top Wall Streeters
articles.snippet: People in a wide range of jobs, accustomed to year-end bonuses to meet their expenses, are trimming back.
articles.abstract: People in a wide range of jobs, accustomed to year-end bonuses to meet their expenses, are trimming back.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not just Wall Street executives who banked on receiving year-end bonuses to support their lifestyles when the economy was booming. A more muted form of the bonus culture extends across the United States.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Fines Didn’t Avert Stanford Group Case
articles.snippet: Years before it was accused of fraud, regulators found violations but let the Stanford Group off with modest fines.
articles.abstract: Years before it was accused of fraud, regulators found violations but let the Stanford Group off with modest fines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Years before the Stanford Group was accused in a worldwide fraud, American financial regulators found significant securities violations at the company that some experts say were telltale signs of deeper problems. But each time the regulators ultimately let the company off with relatively small fines, records show.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Modifying Mortgages Can Be Tricky
articles.snippet: Some mortgage companies view foreclosure as more profitable and expedient than loan modifications.
articles.abstract: Some mortgage companies view foreclosure as more profitable and expedient than loan modifications.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — When her brother could no longer help support her, Luzetta Reeves asked her small mortgage company to cut her monthly payments. It did — by 11 percent — making it possible for her to afford her house here on her modest fixed income.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and John Leland

articles.headline: As Others Fled Venezuela, Stanford Saw a Chance
articles.snippet: As much as 30 percent of Stanford International Bank’s $8 billion in reported assets last year came from Venezuelans.
articles.abstract: As much as 30 percent of Stanford International Bank’s $8 billion in reported assets last year came from Venezuelans.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  In 2005, foreign investors were growing nervous about Venezuela as President Hugo Chávez began asserting greater control of the economy, but Stanford Group decided it was time to put down stakes.

articles.headline: Bankruptcy Could Be More Costly
articles.snippet: General Motors and Chrysler have threatened that they will need $125 billion to finance bankruptcy if they do not receive the additional federal aid they are requesting.
articles.abstract: General Motors and Chrysler have threatened that they will need $125 billion to finance bankruptcy if they do not receive the additional federal aid they are requesting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Businesses filing for bankruptcy need loans to work out their troubles, or face liquidation.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In Budget Deal, California Shuts $41 Billion Gap
articles.snippet: Economists say that California’s budget foreshadows the difficult choices other state legislatures will soon face as the economy worsens.
articles.abstract: Economists say that California’s budget foreshadows the difficult choices other state legislatures will soon face as the economy worsens.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Take-home pay for Californians is about to shrink. Jeans, hammers, burgers and fries will cost more. Public school children will make do with old textbooks and find more classmates sitting next to them. Parents will receive fewer tax benefits, and state university students will pay 9 percent more in tuition.
